summary: Today saw several notable developments in ASR research. A new paper proposes a streaming Conformer variant that achieves sub-100ms latency while maintaining competitive WER on LibriSpeech. Meanwhile, HuggingFace saw the release of a fine-tuned Whisper model optimized for medical transcription, and a new multilingual dataset covering 15 low-resource African languages was published.
ideas: Streaming ASR can now achieve sub-100ms latency without significant quality degradation using chunked attention patterns
Domain-specific fine-tuning of Whisper continues to show strong results, particularly for medical terminology
The gap in ASR performance for low-resource African languages is being actively addressed with new curated datasets
Self-supervised pre-training on unlabeled speech data remains the most effective approach for low-resource settings

papers.title: StreamConformer: Ultra-Low Latency Streaming ASR with Chunked Attention
papers.abstract: We propose StreamConformer, a novel architecture for streaming automatic speech recognition that achieves sub-100ms latency while maintaining competitive word error rates.

papers.title: WhisperMed: Domain-Adapted Speech Recognition for Clinical Documentation
papers.abstract: We present WhisperMed, a fine-tuned version of Whisper Large V3 specifically optimized for medical transcription tasks, achieving 12% relative WER reduction on clinical datasets.

papers.title: AfriSpeech-15: A Multilingual ASR Dataset for 15 African Languages
papers.abstract: We introduce AfriSpeech-15, a carefully curated multilingual speech dataset covering 15 African languages with over 2,000 hours of transcribed audio.
